A lot of twists and deaths. I feel like: In some ways\, Episode VIII was an excellent middle movie in a trilogy: It was exciting; kept me on the edge of my seat and engaged; and the plot and characters took me in directions I had not anticipated. I particularly liked Luke’s wrestling with internal demons. And\, the Rey-Kylo Ren interaction was fascinating. So\, on one level\, I loved the movie. (SPOILERS follow) However\, the entire “escaping rebels” sub-plot had more holes than a colander. For example\, Poe\, who is supposedly the rebels’ shining example of military leadership\, spent most of the movie being a villain. Let’s see\, Poe disobeyed a direct order and his action resulted in all of the rebel bombers being destroyed; he authorized Finn’s secret and ultimately useless side mission; and he led a mutiny. Frankly\, I found it unbelievable that those decisions didn’t get him pushed out of an airlock or at least having his credibility so damaged that no one would follow him. Also\, the Finn-Rose segment’s only purpose seemed to be so that Finn would have something to do in this movie. By the way\, how did DJ know the rebels were escaping using cloaking technology? Neither Finn nor Rose knew that. So\, when I think about these and some other plot problems\, I’m left being very disappointed in this movie and worried for the future. Specifically\, will discordant\, but exciting action now be more important than coherent\, captivating storytelling?
